sect2.title: Changes to &foreach;
sect2.para: Minor changes have been made to the behaviour of the &foreach; control structure, primarily around the handling of the internal array pointer and modification of the array being iterated over.

sect3.title: &foreach; no longer changes the internal array pointer
sect3.para: Prior to PHP 7, the internal array pointer was modified while an array was being iterated over with &foreach;. This is no longer the case, as shown in the following example:
sect3.informalexample:
<?php
$array = [0, 1, 2];
foreach ($array as &$val) {
    var_dump(current($array));
}
?>

   
   &example.outputs.5;
   

int(1)
int(2)
bool(false)

   
   &example.outputs.7;
   

int(0)
int(0)
int(0)

sect3.title: &foreach; by-value operates on a copy of the array
sect3.para: When used in the default by-value mode, &foreach; will now operate on a copy of the array being iterated rather than the array itself. This means that changes to the array made during iteration will not affect the values that are iterated.

sect3.title: &foreach; by-reference has improved iteration behaviour
sect3.para: When iterating by-reference, &foreach; will now do a better job of tracking changes to the array made during iteration. For example, appending to an array while iterating will now result in the appended values being iterated over as well:
sect3.informalexample:
<?php
$array = [0];
foreach ($array as &$val) {
    var_dump($val);
    $array[1] = 1;
}
?>

   
   &example.outputs.5;
   

int(0)

   
   &example.outputs.7;
   

int(0)
int(1)

sect3.title: Iteration of non-Traversable objects
sect3.para: Iterating over a non-Traversable object will now have the same behaviour as iterating over by-reference arrays. This results in the improved behaviour when modifying an array during iteration also being applied when properties are added to or removed from the object.
